title: Erdős Problem #795
description: Determine tight bounds for g(n), the maximum size of a subset of {1,...,n} with all subset products distinct.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős introduced the function g(n) in 1966, studying sets where every subset has a unique product. This connects to the classical study of primitive sets and multiplicative structures in number theory. The problem asks whether the natural construction using primes and prime squares is essentially optimal.
overview.problemStatement: Let g(n) be the maximal size of A ⊆ {1,...,n} such that the products ∏_{a∈S} a are distinct for all S ⊆ A. Is it true that g(n) ≤ π(n) + π(n^{1/2}) + o(n^{1/2}/log n)?
overview.proofStrategy: Raghavan (2025) establishes both tight upper and lower bounds. The upper bound uses careful analysis of how non-prime elements can coexist with primes while maintaining distinct products. The lower bound constructs explicit sets using primes, squares of primes, and some cubes of primes.
keyInsights: Optimal sets consist primarily of primes (unique factorization ensures distinct products)
Squares of small primes add π(√n) elements without creating collisions
Cubes of primes contribute about π(∛n)/3 additional elements
The error term n^{5/12+o(1)} is significantly smaller than π(√n)

sections.title: Problem Overview
sections.summary: Introduction to the distinct subset products problem, with Erdős's original bound and Raghavan's solution.

sections.title: Basic Definitions
sections.summary: Definition of distinct subset products and the function g(n) measuring maximum set size.

sections.title: Erdős's Original Bound
sections.summary: Erdős's 1966 result: g(n) ≤ π(n) + O(n^{1/2}/log n).

sections.title: Raghavan's Solution
sections.summary: The 2025 resolution: tight upper and lower bounds pinning g(n) to π(n) + π(√n) + Θ(π(∛n)).

sections.title: Natural Constructions
sections.summary: How primes and prime powers form optimal sets with distinct subset products.

sections.title: Structure of Optimal Sets
sections.summary: Analysis showing optimal sets decompose into primes, prime squares, and a small remainder.

sections.title: Connection to Sidon Sets
sections.summary: Relationship between distinct products and multiplicative Sidon sets.

sections.title: Examples
sections.summary: Concrete examples illustrating the distinct products property and small values of g(n).

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #795 is SOLVED. Raghavan (2025) proved g(n) = π(n) + π(n^{1/2}) + Θ(π(n^{1/3})), confirming that the natural construction of primes plus prime squares is essentially optimal, with a small contribution from cube roots.
conclusion.implications: This resolves a 60-year-old question about multiplicative structure in sets of integers. The techniques connect prime number theory with combinatorial optimization.
openQuestions: What is the exact leading constant in the π(n^{1/3}) term?
How does g(n) behave for specific sequences like arithmetic progressions?
What are analogues for distinct subset sums versus products?
